attributes.title: Referral trajectories in patients with vertigo, dizziness and balance disorders (VDB) and their impact on mobility, social participation and health-related quality of life – Results from the longitudinal multicenter study MobilE-TRA
attributes.description: Our study, in an explorative and quantitative approach, will aim at extracting existent referral trajectories of visited physicians in an outpatient setting as well as existent clusters of similar referral trajectories in Germany. We will then examine, which patient characteristics do predict the membership of a certain cluster before we finally will analyze the potential influence of cluster membership on the patient’s mobility, social participation and health-related quality of life.

attributes.title: Do uncanny valley perceptions mediate the effect of transformed virtual representations of the self on biases toward AIs?

q1.value: Do uncanny valley perceptions mediate the effect of transformed virtual representations of the self on biases toward AIs?

q3.value: This study examines how uncanny valley perceptions can moderate and/or mediate the effects of pro or anti-AI persuasive messages in self-TalkingHead, other-TalkingHead, and audio-only delivery conditions.

q4.value:
(H1) individuals will endorse more unfavorable (i.e., dystopian) instead of favorable (i.e., utopian) attitudes toward AI-technologies 8 following exposure to AI-generated messages, especially if such messages feature a transformed version of the self instead of a stranger’s face or is delivered via audio with no transformed face (control). 

(H2) uncanny valley perceptions will mediate the effects of AI-generated messages featuring transformed versions of the self on attitudes toward AI-technologies. 

(Research question 1) does exposure to pro or anti AI statements previously recorded by humans influence their attitudes if played back by talking-head virtual characters?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: While the research assistants are aware of which treatments the human subjects receive based on random assignment, the research assistants are not aware of the meaning or purpose of these treatments. RAs are not aware of the hypotheses and are not involved with data analysis.

question.value: 3 x 2 between subjects design with (Modalities: Self-TalkingHead playback condition, Stranger-TalkingHead playback condition, Audio playback condition), and (Message: pro-AI media message, anti-AI media message).

q9.value: Participants were assigned to each condition based on a random numbers table.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Participants have been recruited through the University of California, Davis, SONA System. Participants have been granted 1 SONA credit for arriving to the study on time.  SONA credits are commonly utilized by students for extra credit, to be determined by their professors. Participants must be at least 18 years old at time of study participation.

q13.value: We have collected a sample size of 228 participants.  These 228 participants will be analyzed in our TalkingHeads study. Participants may be eliminated from the analysis if they did not fully comply with the protocol.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis.  G*Power revealed we needed a minimum of 30 participants per factorial condition (for a total of 180 participants) to achieve our desired statistical significance given our predicted effect size.

q15.value: We collected participants the entirety of the Fall 2019 quarter at UC Davis.  We ceased participant collection upon the termination of the Fall 2019 quarter.

question.value: 3(Modality: avatar with participant face; avatar with a stranger's face; audio) x 2(Message: Pro or Anti AIs)

Bias against AIs: the degree to which participants feel biased against AIs, measured with 19 1-7 Likert scale questions.

Uncanny valley perceptions:  the degree to which participants felt unease after consuming the media message, measured with 20 1-7 Likert scale questions.
Means will be calculated using SPSS.
For all hypotheses we will use PROCESS Model 4 (Hayes, 2019).

attributes.title: The impact of formal explanations on kindhood and essentialism

q1.value: The impact of formal explanations on kindhood and essentalism

q3.value: Follow-up to earlier project (https://osf.io/7dmr9/), which investigated how formal explanations may support a structural rather than essentialist interpretation, when structural context information is present. This study investigates the effect of formal explanations on a category's kindhood and essentialism, measured separately.

q4.value: Hearing a formal explanation, relative to hearing a specific control statement, will increase ratings of kindhood more so than ratings of essentialism.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants are randomly assigned to one of 3 conditions - formal explanations, generics, or specific control wording. Participants read statements worded in their given condition about properties of a novel social category, Zarpies, drawn from Noyes & Keil, 2019 (which in turn is drawn from Rhodes, Leslie & Tworek, 2012). Participants then receive measures of kindhood and essentialism drawn from Noyes & Keil, 2019 study 1.

q9.value: The order of the kindhood measures and essentialism measures will be counterbalanced, so either kindhood measures first and essentalism measures second, or vice versa.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Adults recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk using TurkPrime who are located in the US, over 18 years of age, and have at least a 98% approval rate.

q13.value: We will aim for 150 participants total, 50 in each of the 3 conditions.

question.value: Participants in the formal explanation condition will read formal explanations of the form "She/he.... because she/he is a Zarpie." Participants in the generics condition will read generic statements of the form "Zarpies....". Participants in the specific control condition will read specific variations of the generic statements of the form "This Zarpie....".

We will use 3 measures of kindhood (inherent similarity, heterogeneous [reverse-coded], inductive potential) and 4 measures of essentialism (internal cause, constructed category [reverse-coded], constructed boundaries [reverse-coded], immutability) borrowed directly from Noyes & Keil, 2019, study 1.
Each measure is a 6-point Likert scale that will be coded 0-1 (or 1-0 for reverse-coded measures) in evenly spaced intervals, and will be averaged into an overall measure of kindhood or essentialism.
Linear mixed effects model with condition (formal explanation, generic, specific), measure (kind, essence), and their interaction, with participant as a random intercept.

q22.value: Participants who fail the attention check (don't select that this study involved "Learning about Zarpies and answering multiple choice questions about them") will be excluded.

q24.value: Replication of Noyes & Keil, 2019 study 1 finding that generics (compared to specific wording) increase kindhood more so than essentalism. Exploratory analysis to compare effects of generics and formal explanations on kindhood and essentialism.

q25.value: Study design and stimuli drawn from Noyes & Keil, 2019, PNAS, study 1.

comments.value:
In prior studies, we found that framing economic inequality in terms of lower-class disadvantage increased support for collective action (i.e., sharing an infographic on social media, support for attending a protest), in comparison to framing economic inequality in terms of upper-class advantage.

In the current study, we aim to test if we replicate this effect using experimental materials (i.e., infographics) that do not reference a health inequality fact that was included in the previous studies' materials. Thus, the experiment is identical to our prior experiments, except that we removed one piece of information from the inequality frame infographics—the item that described differences in health outcomes ("Medical professionals spend more [less] time and give more [less] accurate diagnoses when treating upper-class [lower-class] patients"). The revised infographic describes 4 (not 5, as was the case in prior studies) pieces of information, framed either as upper-class advantages or lower-class disadvantages. 

A power analysis revealed that we need 1054 participants for 90% power to detect a small effect. We chose to calculate power based on a traditional small effect size, given that we anticipate that the revised infographic might represent a somewhat weaker manipulation than the prior studies' infographic, because it is shorter and includes less information. We aim to collect 1100 participants as we will exclude participants who were not raised in the United States. 

Participants are randomly assigned to read one of the two infographics (advantage frame vs. disadvantage frame). Participants then answer the same two 2 items that measured of support for collective action in our previous studies (i.e., sharing an infographic on social media, support for attending a protest). 

Our primary prediction is that an infographic that describes economic inequality in terms of lower-class disadvantage (without referencing differences in health outcomes) increases support for collective action, compared to an infographic that describes economic inequality in terms of upper-class advantage (without referencing differences in health outcomes).

q1.value: The effect of framing on retirement planning.

q3.value: This experiment serves as a follow-up to two prior pre-registered studies in which I explored whether people allocate money differently to their retirement if retirement is framed as an investment ("investing in your retirement), as saving ("saving for your retirement"), or as a contribution ("contributing to your retirement"). This study serves as a replication to two prior experiments, as well as an extension of exploratory analyses found in the prior studies.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Framing retirement as investing will increase the money people allocate to their retirement vs. framing retirement as a) saving or as b) contributing. 

Hypothesis 2: Framing retirement as saving will increase the money people allocate to their retirement vs. framing retirement as contributing. 

Hypothesis 3: The more retired persons one knows, the more they will a) allocate money to their retirement fund; b) find retirement planning to be important; and c) talk about retirement more with others. 

Hypothesis 4: The positive relation between the number of retired persons one knows and the amount of money one would allocate to their retirement fund will be mediated by a) greater importance placed on retirement planning; and b) greater time spent talking about retirement to others. 

Hypothesis 5: The amount of money one allots to their retirement fund will be a) positively associated with the enjoyment of saving money; and b) negatively associated with the enjoyment of spending money.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a between-subjects design with three conditions (frame: invest vs. save vs. contribute).

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three conditions using the randomization algorithm of our survey software (SurveyGizmo). The order of presentation of all dependent measures will be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Although the data from the study were collected via MTurk, they have not yet been examined nor downloaded from the survey software.

question.value: Participants were recruited via MTurk. They were paid $0.36 for partaking in this study. Participants were required to be at least 18 years of age, be U.S. residents, and be working either part- or full-time while not identifying as retired.

q13.value: The sample size is 500. This was based on financial constraints in compensation of participants (i.e., the maximum amount of money that was able to be spent on this study).

q14.value: The sample size was determined by financial constraints.

q15.value: Data collection stopped when the desired number of subjects partook in the study.

question.value: The manipulated variable is based on a task used by Hershfield et al. (2011). In this task, participants are given a hypothetical $1,000 that they are able to allocate to five different domains as they wished. The five domains were: buying something nice for oneself; buying something nice for another person; using it to pay debt; putting it in a savings account; and depositing the money in a retirement account. The latter entailed the manipulation of this study. For participants in the investment frame condition, the domain read "invest it in your retirement fund." For participants in the saving frame condition, the domain read "save it in a retirement fund." Participants in the contribution condition saw "contribute it to a retirement fund."

Participants will answer questions pertaining to how important retirement preparation is to their current financial planning, how interesting they find retirement planning to be, how often they talk about retirement with others, how much they enjoy saving and spending money, how pessimistic/optimistic they are about comfortably retiring, how many retired persons one knows, the first three words that come to mind when people think about retirement, as well as a set of demographic questions. 

The survey in its entirety, which includes exact question wording and measurement, is included as a part of this application

question.value:
I will be using non-parametric statistical methods to test the hypotheses because the interest is in differences between distributions (distributions of monetary allocations), rather than particular parameters. Furthermore, it is expected that the amount of money allotted to retirement will not be neither normally distributed nor symmetrical. 

When examining correlations, I will be using Spearman rank correlations; when examining differences between conditions, I will use a Kruskal-Wallis test, and when examining differences between conditions, I will use Mann-Whitney U tests. 

To my knowledge, there is no current statistical procedure to examine mediation using nonparametric statistics. For this test, I will use OLS regressions to compute slopes and SEs, and use a Monte Carlo non-parametric simulation method (Preacher & Selig, 2012) to test mediation.

q22.value:
People will be excluded based on five conditions: 

1. They fail an attention check measure.
2. They did not complete the dependent measure correctly (i.e., total amount of money is not 1,000).
3. They reported that their answers should not be kept for analyses. 
4. They did not complete the survey in its entirety.
5. They reported to be retired on a question assessing employment status.

q25.value:
References:

Hershfield, H. E., Goldstein, D. G., Sharpe, W. F., Fox, J., Yeykelis, L., Carstensen, L. L., & Bailenson, J. N. (2011). Increasing saving behavior through age-progressed renderings of the future self. Journal of Marketing Research, 48, 23-37.

Preacher, K. J., & Selig, J. P. (2012). Advantages of Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals for Indirect Effects. Communication Methods and Measures, 6, 77-98.

attributes.title: The Effect Of Organizational Support On Work Satisfaction In Regional Secretariat Employees In Pariaman District
attributes.description: Human resources are one of the resources that exist in a company besides other resources, for example capital, materials, machinery in the company, so that it becomes useful. For this reason, companies are beginning to strive to excel in such competitive competition by trying to create quality and presentative human resources. This study aims to provide evidence that to determine whether or not there is an influence of organizational support on the work satisfaction of the Regional Secretariat Staff in Pariaman Regency. Data collection is done by survey method with a questionnaire. The data analysis technique used in this study is descriptive and quantitative analysis. The data collected is primary and secondary data which can be classified as independent variables and dependent variables. Organizational Support (influence variable), and Job Satisfaction in Regional Secretariat Staff of Pariaman Regency (affected variable). Testing the hypothesis in this study using a simple linear regression test. Based on the results of the study, it is known that there is a positive and significant influence between organizational support for and Job Satisfaction in the Regional Secretariat Staff of Pariaman Regency, obtained by a calculation that is greater than the Ttable where 2.806> 2.015 with a significance of 0.007 <0.05.

Organizational Support (influence variable), and Job Satisfaction in Regional Secretariat Staff of Pariaman Regency (affected variable). Testing the hypothesis in this study using a simple linear regression test. Based on the results of the study, it is known that there is a positive and significant influence between organizational support for and Job Satisfaction in the Regional Secretariat Staff of Pariaman Regency, obtained by a calculation that is greater than the Ttable where 2.806> 2.015 with a significance of 0.007 <0.05.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Study 2: race and discipline of gender transgressions

other.value:
As a manipulation check, participants will be asked whether it is more likely that [student’s name] is Black or White. We will use a chi-squared test to examine whether race perceptions differ between the ‘Black’ and ‘White’ race conditions. We will also measure participants' response to a potential control variable by asking participants to guess the likelihood that the student is from a low-income neighborhood (from 1, not at all, to 7, extremely).

For exploratory purposes, we will also examine the likelihood of extending restorative resources and giving punitive responses for the violations (profanity and insubordination) separately.

sample.value: We aim to run 215 participants with the goal of achieving a sample size of at least 194 after exclusions (with n = 194 we can detect ηp2 = .03 with 80% power, alpha = .05, correlation among repeated measures = .5, ANOVA: repeated measures, between factors) (G*Power software; Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009).

analyses.value: We will use a mixed design ANOVA to examine whether there is an effect of race (between-subjects), response type (within-subjects) and an interaction between these two factors on responses to the misbehavior.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who fail the attention check and/or respond that they answered randomly

dependent.value:
Restorative Response. Participants will rate “How likely is it that you would schedule a student conference with the [student’s name] to invite her to see how her behavior was harmful, give her an opportunity to take responsibility, and collaboratively create a plan of action with her to make things right?” and “How likely is it that you would set up a problem-solving circle with [student’s name] and a trained peer mediator to discuss what happened, what [student’s name] was thinking at the time, who has been affected by her behavior, and what she needs to do to make things right?” separately on scales ranging from 1, not at all, to 7, extremely. These items will be averaged to create a ‘restorative response’ score.

Punitive Response. Participants will rate “How likely is it that you would send [student’s name] to the principal’s office?” and “How likely is it that you would give [student’s name] after school detention?” separately on scales ranging from 1, not at all, to 7, extremely. These items will be averaged to create a ‘punitive response’ score.

conditions.value: There will be 2 between-subject conditions (Black vs. White) and 2 within-subject conditions (restorative responses vs. punitive responses). Participants in the ‘Black’ condition will evaluate misbehavior by students with stereotypically Black names, whereas students in the ‘White’ conditions will evaluate misbehavior by students with stereotypically White names. All participants will respond to the restorative and punitive outcomes.

hypothesis.value: We are interested in examining whether race is heightening perceptions of gender-inappropriate behavior in educational settings and influencing how teachers respond to misbehavior in the classroom. Specifically, we will test whether the race of the female student influences the likelihood of extending positive, restorative resources and punitive measures when a behavioral infraction has occurred. Participants will be asked to imagine themselves as a teacher at Lincoln High School. They will then read a mock school discipline record of a student that outlines two violations (profanity and insubordination (the order of violations will be counterbalanced)). Race of the student will be manipulated by using stereotypically Black (Lakisha and Tamika) or stereotypically White (Molly and Katie) names (names within race will be counterbalanced). Participants will be told that the violations occurred in their classroom in in the last month and the second violation occurred today. As the student’s teacher, they are responsible for deciding how to respond to the second violation. They will then be asked how likely it is that they would extend two forms of restorative practices (student-teacher conference and peer mediation) and two forms of punitive practices (after-school detention and being sent to the principal’s office) to the student. We predict that participants will be less likely to extend restorative resources and more likely to respond punitively when the student is Black (vs. White).

attributes.title: Predicting attitudes toward posthumous organ donation from conscientiousness and religiosity

q1.value: Predicting attitudes toward posthumous organ donation from conscientiousness and religiosity

q3.value:
Twenty people a day die from not having access to an organ for transplantation, and almost 114,000 people in the United States need a lifesaving organ transplant (“Facts and Myths about Transplant,” 2019). It is imperative to the lives of those waiting on organs to better understand the barriers to becoming an organ donor. The purpose of this study is to better understand the relationship between conscientiousness and religiosity and attitudes toward organ donation. A quasi-experimental/correlational study will be used to explore relationships between personality, religiosity, and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. Approximately 2,900 undergraduate students from a small, denominationally affiliated university in the Midwest will be asked to complete an online survey consisting of measures of personality, religiosity, and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. There are four main research questions in this study: 

RQ1: Does conscientiousness predict attitudes toward posthumous organ donation? 
RQ2: Does religiosity predict attitudes toward posthumous organ donation?
RQ3: Do any of the six facets of conscientiousness (self-efficacy, orderliness, dutifulness, achievement-striving, self-discipline, and cautiousness) predict attitudes toward posthumous organ donation? 
RQ4: Are there differences between registered donors and non-registered donors in terms of attitude toward organ donation?

q4.value:
RQ1 Correlational Hypothesis (Directional): 
Hypothesis 1: There is a positive relationship between conscientiousness and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 

RQ2 Correlational Hypothesis (Directional): 
Hypothesis 2: There is a positive relationship between religiosity and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 

RQ3 Correlational Hypotheses (Directional): 
Hypothesis 3 (Correlational, Directional): There is a positive relationship between self-efficacy and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 
Hypothesis 4 (Correlational, Directional): There is a positive relationship between orderliness and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 
Hypothesis 5 (Correlational, Directional): There is a positive relationship between dutifulness and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 
Hypothesis 6 (Correlational, Directional): There is a positive relationship between achievement-striving and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 
Hypothesis 7 (Correlational, Directional): There is a positive relationship between self-discipline and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 
Hypothesis 8 (Correlational, Directional): There is a positive relationship between cautiousness and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. 

RQ4 Quasi-Experimental Hypothesis (Directional): Hypothesis 9: Registered donors will have more positive attitudes toward organ donation than non-registered potential donors.

question.value: A quasi-experimental/correlational study will be used to explore relationships between personality, religiosity, and attitudes toward posthumous organ donation. Therefore, no variables will be manipulated.

Conscientiousness is often described as a person who is “self-controlled, responsible to others, hardworking, orderly, and rule-abiding” (Roberts, Lejuez, Krueger, Richards, & Hill, 2014). Costa and McCrae's (1992) NEO-PI-R Facets of conscientiousness are self-efficacy, orderliness, dutifulness, achievement-striving, self-discipline, and cautiousness. Self-efficacy is defined as beliefs about one’s own capacity to accomplish a task, and it often contributes to motivation (Bandura, 1997). Orderliness is described as being “prepared.” Tendencies related to orderliness include neatness and cleanliness (Roberts et al., 2014). High dutifulness is characterized by following rules in contrast to breaking them, and achievement-striving is described as working hard versus just doing enough to get by (P. T. Costa & McCrae, 2008). Self-discipline is illustrated by someone who does their chores right away versus a person who wastes their time (P. T. Costa & McCrae, 2008). The sixth trait of cautiousness is described as not rushing into things and avoiding mistakes (P. Costa, Costa, & Mccrae, 2016). The facets of conscientiousness (self-efficacy, orderliness, dutifulness, achievement-striving, and self-discipline) will be assessed using Costa and McCrae's (1992) NEO-PI-R Facets scale taken from the International Personality Item Pool (n.d.). The scale consists of 60 statements (10 for each facet) measured on a five-point Likert scale with endpoints that range from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 5 (Strongly Agree). 

For the purpose of this research, religiosity and spirituality are almost synonymous since they are measured with the same scale. However, religiosity is defined as the more outward, institutional aspects of religion (e.g., religious practices, organized religious doctrines); however, spirituality is defined as the more inward, personal aspects of religion (e.g., subjective spiritual experiences, personal spiritual beliefs, etc.) (Schettino, 2012). Religiosity will be assessed using the Spirituality/Religiousness scale taken from the International Personality Item Pool (n.d.). It will be measured on a five-point Likert scale with endpoints that range from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 5 (Strongly Agree).

Conscientiousness. The facets of conscientiousness (self-efficacy, orderliness, dutifulness, achievement-striving, and self-discipline) will be assessed using Costa and McCrae's (1992) NEO-PI-R Facets scale taken from the International Personality Item Pool (n.d.). The scale consists of 60 statements (10 for each facet) measured on a five-point Likert scale with endpoints that range from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 5 (Strongly Agree). After reverse scoring of the indicated items, an overall score for each facet will be obtained, and the overall score for conscientious will be determined as well.   

Spirituality/Religiousness. Religiosity will be assessed using the Spirituality/Religiousness scale taken from the International Personality Item Pool (n.d.). It will be measured on a five-point Likert scale with endpoints that range from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 5 (Strongly Agree). After reverse scoring of the indicated items, an overall score for religiosity will be determined with higher scores indicating a higher level of religiosity. 

Organ Donation Attitude Scale. Attitude toward donating organs will be measured using two methods. One method will utilize the Organ Donation Attitude Scale (ODAS). This test consists of 20 statements that will be scored on a four-point Likert scale ranging from strongly agreed (4 points), agreed (3 points), disagreed (2 points), or strongly disagreed (1 point). Items 2, 13, 14, and 16 will be reversed scored. Two questions do not directly pertain to organ donation and will not be scored. The scores range from 18-72, and higher scores reflect more positive views toward organ donation.  Two questions will be used to create binary groups for the ANOVA. Question 6 states, "I am willing to have organs donated after my death," and Question 
7 states, "I have signed an organ donor card or the back of my driver’s license." Participants who answer agree or strongly agree will be grouped together while those who answer disagree or strongly disagree will be grouped in a separate group.

Multiple regression analysis will be carried out to predict positive attitudes toward organ donation based on conscientiousness and religiosity which addresses the first three hypotheses. It will be determined if conscientiousness, the facets of conscientiousness, and/or religiosity are significant predictors of positive attitudes toward organ donation. Since the scales use different maximum point values, standardized 𝜷 coefficients will need to be used. After the variables have been standardized, it will be determined how much positive attitudes toward organ donation increase for each predictor. The greatest predictor of positive attitudes toward organ donation will be determined as well.  

Using an ANOVA, being a registered organ donor or not will be the independent variable since it is a nominal/categorical level. The dependent variable will be scored from the Organ Donation Attitude Scale. It will be able to detect differences between the two groups.

q20.value: Since the scales use different maximum point values, standardized 𝜷 coefficients will need to be used. After the variables have been standardized, it will be determined how much positive attitudes toward organ donation increase for each predictor. The greatest predictor of positive attitudes toward organ donation will be determined as well.

q21.value: A standard p<0.05 criteria will be used for determining if the ANOVA and regression are significant. A post-hoc Tukey-Kamer test will adjust for the multiple comparisons.

q22.value: There is no manipulation check present to exclude samples from the analyses. A normal distribution will be graphed to determine how and if outliers need to be removed.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete a part of the three indices (ODAS, one of the six facets of conscientiousness, or religiosity/spirituality) or the demographic questionnaire, the subject’s data will not be included in the analysis when those specific indices are analyzed. For example, if a participant does not answer a question pertaining to self-efficacy but does answer all of the questions for the other five facets of conscientiousness. The participant’s data will still be analyzed for the remaining five facets.

q24.value: Several demographic traits will be compared with the main variables (conscientiousness, religiosity, and organ donor status) to explore potentially interesting relationships and to determine how applicable this study to a more diverse population.

After the variables have been standardized, it will be determined how much positive attitudes toward organ donation increase for each predictor. The greatest predictor of positive attitudes toward organ donation will be determined as well.  

Using an ANOVA, being a registered organ donor or not will be the independent variable since it is a nominal/categorical level. The dependent variable will be scored from the Organ Donation Attitude Scale. It will be able to detect differences between the two groups.

attributes.title: Word Error Rate of Speech-to-Text for Native vs. Non-native speakers

q1.value: Word Error Rate of Speech-to-Text for Native and Non-native English Speakers

q3.value: Automatic speech recognition (ASR) can have word error rates as low as 5-6% (Huang, 2017; Saon, 2017). However, accented speech input can be a weak point for ASRs and increase these word-error rates. This can be an area of concern for the accessibility of automatic speech recognition services. Using the same ASRs and similar methodology of Glasser (2019), which used speech from deaf and hard-of-hearing participants, this study compares the word-error rates (WERs) of three ASRs when given input from native English speakers and non-native English speakers whose first language is Spanish. Audio files will be collected from the two groups of participants to be used as input into the three ASRs.

q4.value:
1. Effect of native language - The word error rate (WER) of automatically recognized speech from non-native English speakers will be greater than the WER of automatically recognized speech from native English speakers.

2. Effect of ASR - There is no significant difference between WERs of the 3 ASRs.

3. Interaction effect - We predict that there is no interaction effect between whether the speaker is a native speaker and the type of ASR.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study is a 2 X 3 design with 2 groups (native English control group, non-native English with Spanish as a first language group), and 3 automatic speech recognition services (Microsoft web translator, Microsoft Powerpoint Translator, IBM Watson Speech-to-Text).
- Between groups of native vs nonnative English factor
- Repeated measures of ASR factor

In other words, audio files will be collected from the 2 groups of participants to be used as input into 3 ASRs.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific in two separate groups, and paid $1.30 (rate of $7.80/hr for completing the study in an expected time of 10 minutes). The native English speaker group will be recruited in one study with pre-screening requirements of English monolingual, Fluency in English, and United States nationality, while the non-native English speaker group will be recruited with pre-screening requirements of Spanish as a first language, Fluency in English, and United States residence.

q13.value: 150 native English participants and 150 non-native English participants

q14.value: While Glasser (2019) had over 600 participants, this sample size was chosen to reasonably stay within funding constraints and the timeline for the study.

q15.value: Once 150 participants in each group complete the study through Prolific, data collection will stop.

question.value:
The Word-error-rate of each ASR output (3 ASR outputs per participant) is the dependent variable and will be calculated using the SCLITE toolkit from the NIST Scoring Toolkit, which divides the errors in the ASR output by the total number of words actually said.

On the demographics form for non-native English speaker participants, the age of acquisition, age of proficiency, self perception of one's accent, and others' perception of one's accent in English will be measured.

A 2 x 3 repeated measures ANOVA will be conducted. Because we have a directional prediction for main effect of native language group, an independent samples t-test will be performed. If there is a main effect of ASR, post-hoc Bonferroni t-tests will be conducted.

If the directional t-test is not significant, a Bayes factor analysis will be conducted to see if there is support for the null.

q20.value: Each audio file will be used as input into each of the 3 ASRs, generating 3 transcripts per file. These transcripts will be compared with the original sentences to calculate a word error rate for that audio file & ASR, using the SCLITE from the NIST SCTK (Scoring Toolkit).

q21.value:
For p-values, we will use p<0.05 for the ANOVA and t-test, and p<.017 for the Bonferroni post-hoc tests (see above "Statistical Models" section).

For Bayes factor analysis, we will use a BF <=1/3 (one-third) as the criterion for evidence for the null.

q22.value: Eliminate audio file from transcript transformation only if the audio file cannot be played or is completely unintelligible.

q23.value: If an audio file does not contain an attempt at reading the full passage given, that file will not be used.

q24.value: Some exploratory analyses may be conducted on the demographic survey's language questions.

q25.value:

Saon, G. (2017, March 7). Reaching new records in speech recognition. IBM. https://www.ibm.com/blogs/watson/2017/03/reaching-new-records-in-speech-recognition/

National Institute of Standards and Technology. SCTK, Github respository, https://github.com/usnistgov/SCTK

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
The Relationship between Emotion Suppression and Sleep: The Moderating Role of Culture

Emotion suppression has been related to lower life satisfaction and an increased risk of physical and mental health problems. However, the negative effect of emotion suppression may not be cross-culturally consistent. We hypothesize that emotion suppression may not be harmful in interdependent cultures in which people are encouraged to suppress their emotions to maintain harmonious relationships with others. The proposed research will thus examine whether culture moderates the relationship between daily use of emotion suppression and sleep, a critical component of health maintenance, in a two-weeks of daily diary study. We predict that emotion suppression will be associated with poor quality of sleep among European Americans, but this relationship will be attenuated or even disappear among East Asians. This prediction will be tested using data from a larger study. The larger study aims to address a different research question (on the moderating role of culture in the relationships between daily affective styles and health) and the data collection is currently underway. Nonetheless, we believe that our proposal is a valid pre-registration because we generated our hypotheses for this proposed study, independent of the on-going data collection for the larger study from which the data for this project will be drawn.

other.value:
Several exploratory measures will be included for the larger study from which the data for this study will be drawn. Three types of exploratory analyses will be conducted.

First, before participating in the daily diary portion of the study, participants will be asked to complete several individual difference measures, including the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI; Buysse, Reynolds, Monk, Berman, & Kupfer, 1989). If two cultural groups differ in their baseline sleep quality, we will use the PSQI score as a covariate in our analysis to adjust for this cultural difference. The baseline questionnaire packet will also include measures that could mediate the hypothesized cultural difference, including the Singelis Self-Construal Scale (Singelis, 1994) and the Dialectical Views of Emotion Scale (Miyamoto et.al, 2014).

Second, daily use of cognitive reappraisal will also be measured in the night diaries through the modified ERS. To understand whether the hypothesized cultural moderation is specific to emotion suppression or is similarly shown for other emotion regulation processes, we will also examine the relationship between cognitive reappraisal and sleep quality between the two cultural groups. In addition, we will examine whether daily emotional experiences (both positive and negative), social support, and stress, which will also be assessed in the night diaries, further moderate the effect of emotion suppression on sleep between the two cultural groups. 

As a part of the larger study described above, participants will be asked to complete a follow-up survey three months later, in which physical and mental health outcomes will be measured. Therefore, we will explore the potential longitudinal effects of emotion suppression on mental and physical health outcomes such as depression, anxiety and physical symptoms for both cultural groups.

sample.value: A sample of 170 individuals (85 East Asians and 85 European Americans) who are 18 years old or above will be recruited. Because we will use data from a larger study that aims to address a different research question (i.e., the moderating role of culture on the relationship between negative emotion and sleep), we conducted a power analysis using G*Power (Erdfelder, Faul, & Buchner, 1996) based on a previous study, which found an association between daily negative affect and poor sleep quality, with a small-to-medium effect size (rs ranged from .2 to .4 depending on negative emotion items, with a mean of .3) (Thomsen, Mehlsen, Christensen & Zachariae, 2003). The power analysis based on the mean correlation coefficient (r = .3) showed that we need 82 participants in each group to detect a significant correlation between negative affect and sleep quality, with a power of .80 (α = 0.05, two-tailed). We will recruit 3 additional people in each cultural group in consideration of potential data attrition, which translates into 170 participants (85 participants in each cultural group).

analyses.value:
Given the nested nature of the data (i.e., daily responses nested within participants), a two-level multilevel modeling (MLM) analysis will be conducted to examine how culture may moderate the effect of daily emotion suppression on sleep. Before the analysis, culture will be effect-coded. Because emotion suppression is likely to vary both across individuals and also across days during the daily diary portion, this variable will be separated into two variables to account for the between-person variance and within-person variance, respectively (see Curran & Baucer, 2011; Hoffman & Stawski, 2009 for the similar approach). The between-person variable will be calculated by subtracting the grand mean of emotion suppression across all participants and all time points from each participant’s averaged score across the 14 days, while the within-person variable will be calculated by subtracting the person-specific mean of emotion suppression across 14 days from each participant’s daily responses.

We will adopt an analytic procedure from prior work to test the MLM model (Sladek et al., 2020). In the first level, each day’s self-reported or behavioral index of sleep quality will be entered as a dependent variable, and the within-person variable of prior day’s use of emotion suppression will be entered as a predictor variable. In the second level, we will include the between-person variable of emotion suppression, culture (East Asian vs. European American), and their interaction as predictor variables. The interaction term in the second level (i.e., Culture x Between-person variable of emotion suppression) will be used to test whether the overall relationship between emotion suppression and sleep collapsing across the 14 days will be moderated by culture. In addition, the cross-level interaction (i.e., Culture x Within-person variable of emotion suppression) will be tested to examine whether culture moderates the day-to-day association between emotion suppression and sleep.

outliers.value: Extreme values on the key study variables (emotion suppression and sleep) will be identified using Cook’s distance criterion. Specifically, extreme data points with a value of Cook's D over 1.0 will be excluded following an established procedure (e.g., Winzeler et. al, 2014). Further, individuals whose actigraphy watch data is noisy or those who have missing actigraphy watch data (e.g., due to technological error) will be excluded from the pertinent analysis. Participants whose compliance rate for the daily diary portion is lower than 50% will also be excluded following an approach from prior work (Hara et al., 2014).

dependent.value:
The hypotheses will be tested using the data from a larger daily diary study of which this study is a part. Both East Asian and European American participants will be asked to fill out two diaries on each day for 14 consecutive days, one in the evening before going to sleep (night diaries) to assess the use of emotion suppression of each day (our predictor variable), and the other in the morning after waking up (morning diaries) to assess sleep quality from the previous night (our dependent variable).  

In the night diaries, a modified version of Emotion Regulation Scale (ERS, Gross & John, 2003) will be used to measure the use of emotion suppression on each day.

In the morning diaries, sleep quality in the prior night will be measured using the Pittsburgh sleep diary (PSD; Monk et al., 1994). Participants will also be asked to wear an actigraphy watch (Philips Actiwatch Spectrum Pro) during the two weeks of daily diary period, through which behavioral information about sleep (e.g. sleep duration) will also be assessed.

hypothesis.value: The proposed study will examine whether the relationship between daily use of emotion suppression and sleep is moderated by culture. Specifically, we hypothesize that emotion suppression will be associated with poor quality of sleep among European Americans. In contrast, we hypothesize that this relationship will be either attenuated or even disappear among East Asians.
